comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Richard III is easy, McMaster was the master in those days, the Capitol is a bum steer, I really think it was the Queens and 1936 for no particular reason!  As regards guessing I've never managed to win the lottery in all the years its been going so you can tell how good I am!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think that the writing on Eason's calendar page says "2nd Month", which is odd.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oh, you're mean to toy with me! I thought you really knew, and I was going to laud you as an example of the power of Flickr...  :D

However, am checking out photos of Anew McMaster. He had a cleft chin so far as I can make out, and there is evidence of a slight dimple in this one...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I doubt that it was the 'unchback, the part is played by one who has (applied) facial deformities and wearing almost rags.  this chap is dressed as a nobleman of some stature.  Waaaaah! I was just about to post this and the anvil dropped "or do you just have a hunch" gawd Carol that's dreadful!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Some puns just cannot be resisted, no matter how hard one tries. One must admit, one didn't try very hard.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: That's in a politically correct society and the setting of the Hunchback was most certainly not!  The story is that he was a recluse, hidden from the world to save them from being shocked by his appearance and all the time he, hidden amongst the other gargoyles, gazed down with interest and longing at what was going on below him!  Surely scruffy and deformed for that storyline?

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: The much-maligned Richard III was given a bad image by Tudor propagandists, no doubt aided by the writings of Thomas More and William Shakespeare. There is no evidence that Richard was ever a hunchback at all ! Had Richard III survived to rule, he would likely have proved himself as adept a king as Edward IV.

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Looks somewhat operatic to me. Any chance this might not be Shakespearean at all but someone in costume for Verdi's opera "Rigoletto"?  Presume this was taken in Dublin so was "Rigoletto" performed there around this time?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56225952@N06] Good suggestion, I think!
